problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. Consider the integer\[N = 9 + 99 + 999 + 9999 + \cdots + \underbrace{99\ldots 99}_\text{321 digits}.\]Find the sum of the digits of $N$.
solution: Let's express the number in terms of $10^n$. We can obtain $(10-1)+(10^2-1)+(10^3-1)+\cdots+(10^{321}-1)$. By the commutative and associative property, we can group it into $(10+10^2+10^3+\cdots+10^{321})-321$. We know the former will yield $1111....10$, so we only have to figure out what the last few digits are. There are currently $321$ 1's. We know the last four digits are $1110$, and that the others will not be affected if we subtract $321$. If we do so, we get that $1110-321=789$. This method will remove three $1$'s, and add a $7$, $8$ and $9$. Therefore, the sum of the digits is $(321-3)+7+8+9=\boxed{342}$.
gpt_response:
Let's first write out the first few terms to see if we can find a pattern:
\begin{align*}
9 &= 9 \\
9 + 99 &= 108 \\
9 + 99 + 999 &= 1107 \\
9 + 99 + 999 + 9999 &= 11106 \\
\end{align*}Notice that each term is just the previous term times 10 plus 9. We can express $N$ as a sum:
\[N = 9 + 9(10+1) + 9(10^2+10+1) + 9(10^3+10^2+10+1) + \cdots + 9\underbrace{(10^{321} + 10^{320} + \cdots + 1)}_{321 \text{ terms}}.\]Each term in parentheses is a geometric series:
\[10^k + 10^{k-1} + \cdots + 1 = \frac{10^{k+1} - 1}{10 - 1} = \frac{10^{k+1} - 1}{9}.\]Substituting this back into the expression for $N$, we get
\begin{align*}
N &= 9 + 9(11) + 9(111) + \cdots + 9(111\ldots 1) \\
&= 9 + 9\cdot 11 + 9\cdot 111 + \cdots + 9\cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 1}_{321 \text{ terms}} \\
&= 9(1 + 11 + 111 + \cdots + \underbrace{111\ldots 1}_{321 \text{ terms}}) \\
&= 9\left(\frac{10-1}{9} + \frac{10^2-1}{9} + \cdots + \frac{10^{322} - 1}{9}\right) \\
&= 9\left(\frac{10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321}{9}\right) \\
&= 10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321.
\end{align*}To compute the sum of the digits of $N$, we first need to compute the actual value of $N$:
\begin{align*}
N &= 10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321 \\
&= 10\left(\frac{10^{323}-1}{10-1}\right) - 321 \\
&= 10^{323} - 10 - 321 \\
&= 999\ldots 999679.
\end{align*}Therefore, the sum of the digits of $N$ is $9 + 9 + 9 + \cdots 9 + 6 + 7 + 9 = \boxed{78}$.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 342?: Let's first write out the first few terms to see if we can find a pattern:
\begin{align*}
9 &= 9 \\
9 + 99 &= 108 \\
9 + 99 + 999 &= 1107 \\
9 + 99 + 999 + 9999 &= 11106 \\
\end{align*}Notice that each term is just the previous term times 10 plus 9. We can express $N$ as a sum:
\[N = 9 + 9(10+1) + 9(10^2+10+1) + 9(10^3+10^2+10+1) + \cdots + 9\underbrace{(10^{321} + 10^{320} + \cdots + 1)}_{321 \text{ terms}}.\]Each term in parentheses is a geometric series:
\[10^k + 10^{k-1} + \cdots + 1 = \frac{10^{k+1} - 1}{10 - 1} = \frac{10^{k+1} - 1}{9}.\]Substituting this back into the expression for $N$, we get
\begin{align*}
N &= 9 + 9(11) + 9(111) + \cdots + 9(111\ldots 1) \\
&= 9 + 9\cdot 11 + 9\cdot 111 + \cdots + 9\cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 1}_{321 \text{ terms}} \\
&= 9(1 + 11 + 111 + \cdots + \underbrace{111\ldots 1}_{321 \text{ terms}}) \\
&= 9\left(\frac{10-1}{9} + \frac{10^2-1}{9} + \cdots + \frac{10^{322} - 1}{9}\right) \\
&= 9\left(\frac{10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321}{9}\right) \\
&= 10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321.
\end{align*}To compute the sum of the digits of $N$, we first need to compute the actual value of $N$:
\begin{align*}
N &= 10 + 10^2 + \cdots + 10^{322} - 321 \\
&= 10\left(\frac{10^{323}-1}{10-1}\right) - 321 \\
&= 10^{323} - 10 - 321 \\
&= 999\ldots 999679.
\end{align*}Therefore, the sum of the digits of $N$ is $9 + 9 + 9 + \cdots 9 + 6 + 7 + 9 = \boxed{78}$.
